person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_068.name: SmithsonTennant
person_068.description: Tennant was a botanist and chemist and knew Davy through agricultural improvements. Appointed Professor of Chemistry at Cambridge University in 1813, he was killed in a riding accident in France. FRSL.

person_003.name: WilliamAllen
person_003.description: Allen was a Quaker who worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Davy asked him to give lectures on natural philosophy at the RI. FRSL.

person_015.name: William HaseldinePepys
person_015.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

person_203.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
person_203.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

person_202.name: Dominique François JeanArago
person_202.description: French mathematician, physicist, astronomer and political liberal. Davy presented him with the Copley Medal in 1825. ForMemRSL.

person_049.name: Louis BernardGuyton de Morveau
person_049.description: French chemist and revolutionary politician who is credited with producing the first systematic method of chemical nomenclature. ForMemRSL.

person_669.name: FelicianoScarpellini
person_669.description: Italian astronomer and abbot; he served as Master of Logic and Metaphysics at Collegio Romano (the Roman College).

person_587.name: Count GirolamoBardi
person_587.description: Italian geologist and mineralogist. He was the director of the Museum of Physics and Natural History of Florence where Davy experimented in 1814.

person_588.name: GiuseppeGazzaris
person_588.description: (Gazzeri) was an Italian chemist who published Compendio d'un trattato elementare di chimica - a chemistry textbook based on the work of the French Chemists.

person_200.name: Domenico LinoMorichini
person_200.description: Italian physican and chemist. Professor of Chemistry at the Univerity of Rome from 1798 to his death. Gave Davy medical advice in his final years. ForMemRSL.

person_784.name: Daniel GabrielFahrenheit
person_784.description: German physicist, inventor, and scientific instrument maker, who invented the mercury-in-glass thermometer. The temperature scale he proposed is named after him. ForMemRSL.

person_123.name: Barnaba Niccolò Maria LuigiChiaramonti
person_123.description: Pope Pius VII, 1800-1823, held prisioner by Buonparte, 1809-1813. In February 1814 Davy and his party stayed in the same inn that Pius had used the week before on his way back to Rome.

person_841.name: ClaudeLorrain
person_841.description: French painter, who lived mostly in Italy; known for his landscapes. Davy knew of his work, mentioning Lorrain in a letter to Mr Poole included in the memoirs published by his brother, John Davy (Memoirs of the Life of Sir Humphry Davy).

person_848.name: FrancescoPetrarch
person_848.description: An Italian poet and scholar, famous for his love sonnets. Davy wrote a poem called 'Vaucluse' inspired by Petrarch's poetry on the river Sorgue and Vaucluse valley in the Provence region of France and called him the 'bard of provence' in another poem, which John Davy published with the title 'Banks of the Rhone'.

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_150.name: William HydeWollaston
person_150.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

person_859.name: JohnLubbock
person_859.description: Sir John Lubbock, 1st Baronet of Lammas, was a merchant, MP and prominent London banker. He helped establish and was a partner in the bank of Lemon, Buller, Finlay and Lubbock of London in 1772. He was also involved in diverse business ventures as a merchant.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_590.name: Henry HallGage
person_590.description: Fourth Viscount Gage (in the Irish peerage) from 1808.  Met Davy in Rome in 1815 who thereafter stayed with him at his seat Firle Place, near Lewes, several times.

person_591.name: JohnRussell
person_591.description: Sixth Duke of Bedford from 1802. A Proprieter of the Royal Institution and member of the Board of Agriculture in which roles he knew Davy.

person_847.name: Roger JosephBoscovich
person_847.description: Physicist, astronomer and mathematician born in Croatia but lived and worked mainly in Italy and France. Boscovich's work makes him one of the forerunners of atomic theory.

person_182.name: Democritus
person_182.description: Pre-Socratic Greek philosopher who proposed a form of atomism.

person_445.name: Pythagoras
person_445.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_012.name: Joseph LouisGay-Lussac
person_012.description: French chemist and physicist, known mostly for his discovery that water is made of two parts hydrogen and one part oxygen by volume (with Alexander von Humboldt), for two laws related to gases, and for his work on alcohol-water mixtures. Became involved in controversies with Davy over various chemical discoveries. ForMemRSL.

person_201.name: Louis JacquesThénard
person_201.description: Held chairs of chemistry at the Collège de France and the Ecole Polytechnique. Worked closely with Gay-Lussac and met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_592.name: Joseph FrédéricBérard
person_592.description: French physician and philosopher in Montpellier where Davy met him on his Continental tour.

person_854.name: DomenicoViviani
person_854.description: Italian botanist; Professor of Botany at the University of Genoa.

person_398.name: NicolasClément
person_398.description: French chemist who worked with his father-in-law, Charles Desormes.

person_008.name: CharlesDesormes
person_008.description: Desormes was a French physicist and chemist. He did most of his scientific work in collaboration with his son-in-law, Nicolas Clément.

person_157.name: André-MarieAmpère
person_157.description: French physicist and mathematician and one of the key figure in the early study of electro-magnetism. Davy met him in Paris in 1813 and they developed a scientific rivalry. ForMemRSL.

person_676.name: BernardCourtois
person_676.description: French chemist who first isolated iodine. though he did not recognise it as an element which Davy did whilst in Paris.

person_206.name: WilliamHenry
person_206.description: Manchester physician and chemist, whose Elements of Experimental Chemistry went through eleven editions. FRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him to refer to the generation of electric current by chemical action.

person_048.name: Nicolas-Théodore deSaussure
person_048.description: Swiss chemist and student of plant physiology who made seminal advances in phytochemistry. ForMemRSL.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_349.name: Jöns JacobBerzelius
person_349.description: Swedish chemist. He discovered the chemical elements cerium and selenium, and was the first to isolate silicon, thorium, titanium, and zirconium. A rival of Davy's whom he met a few times.

person_152.name: Michel EugèneChevreul
person_152.description: French organic chemist. Met Davy when he was in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_050.name: Louis NicolasVauquelin
person_050.description: French pharmacist and chemist who met Davy in Paris in 1813. ForMemRSL.

person_244.name: Martin HeinrichKlaproth
person_244.description: Pharmacist and chemist. Professor of Chemistry in Berlin. ForMemRSL.

person_351.name: François-Étiennede La Roche
person_351.description: Genevan physician, naturalist, chemist, botanist, and ichthyologist.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_690.name: RichardChenevix
person_690.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and playwright. He was known for his sharp cynicism and for engaging in combative criticism. FRSL.

person_011.name: Antoine-Francois deFourcroy
person_011.description: French chemist who collaborated with Lavoisier in standardising chemical nomenclature. Davy as a teenager read some of his work.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of atheism following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_119.name: NapoleonBuonaparte
person_119.description: French general and, as First Consul, 1799-1804, and Emperor, 1804-1815, military dictator of France and the territories it occupied. Established the Volta prize for research electricity and provided Davy with a passport to collect it in Paris in 1813.

person_052.name: GeorgePearson
person_052.description: Physician and chemist who introduced a new systematic nomenclature for inorganic chemistry in English based on that devised by French chemists and confirmed the effacy of vaccination. FRSL.

person_682.name: Heinrich AugustVogel
person_682.description: Professor of Chemistry at the University of Munich.

person_353.name: Edme-FrançoisJomard
person_353.description: French cartographer, engineer, and archaeologist. He was a member of the Institut d'Egypte established by Napoleon.

person_551.name: MichaelFaraday
person_551.description: From 1812 Davy used Faraday as his amanuensis and the following year secured his appointment as laboratory assistant at the Royal Institution. Despite a difficult relationship with Davy, Faraday later became the dominant figure at the Royal Institution and one of the leading scientific personalities of the middle third of the nineteenth century. FRSL.

person_938.name: WilliamKerr
person_938.description: Dates untraced; the nephew of Jane Davy's uncle, William Kerr (1738-1824), a physican of Northampton; one of Jane Davy's executors who had been a medical student at the University of Edinburgh and later a physician and assistant surgeon.

person_070.name: JaneDavy
person_070.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

place_565.name: Terni
place_565.description: Terni is a city in the southern portion of the region of Umbria in central Italy.

place_1074.name: Palazzo Bolognetti
place_1074.description: Now called the Palazzo Nuñez-Torlonia, a 16th-century Renaissance town house in Via della Conciliazione, Rome, Italy.

place_1032.name: Eboli
place_1032.description: An Italian town in the province of Salerno.

place_180.name: Paestum
place_180.description: Paestum was an ancient Greek city on the coast of southern Italy.

place_830.name: Laura
place_830.description: A southern Italian village and hamlet of Capaccio, a municipality in the province of Salerno, Campania.

place_945.name: River Arveyron
place_945.description: Davy is possibly referring to the rivers Arveyron and Arve: the Arveyron rises just above Chamonix in France and is a tributary of the Arve.

place_1033.name: Pont, Côte-d'Or
place_1033.description: Likely a reference to the Pont du Gard, a Roman aqueduct bridge built in the first century AD, located in southern France.

place_1080.name: Florence
place_1080.description: The capital city of the Italian region of Tuscany.

place_243.name: Carrara
place_243.description: Carrara is a city in central Italy.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_700.name: Pontine Marshes
place_700.description: Now agricultural land, the Pontine Marshes are located south-east of Rome.

place_701.name: Cava de' Tirreni
place_701.description: Monte Cavo (Monte Albano) is an extinct volcano in the Alban Hills, near Rome.

place_702.name: Lake of Nemi
place_702.description: A volcanic lake south of Rome, Italy. The lake was sacred to the goddess Diana Nemorensis.

place_704.name: Bay of Naples
place_704.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_705.name: Sele River
place_705.description: The Sele River flows through southwestern Italy and enters the Tyrrhenian Sea close to the ancient city of Paestum.

place_706.name: Temple of Neptune
place_706.description: Roman temple located in Paestum, near Naples, Italy.

place_169.name: Mount Vesuvius
place_169.description: Mount Vesuvius is a somma-stratovolcano located on the Gulf of Naples in Campania, Italy.

place_407.name: Pompeii
place_407.description: An ancient city located in what is now the comune of Pompei near Naples in the Campania region of Italy. Pompeii was buried in volcanic ash in the Eruption of Mount Vesuvius in 79 CE.

place_707.name: Posillipo, a hill in Naples
place_707.description: A district of Naples, Italy, built upon a rock peninsula.

place_709.name: Capri
place_709.description: An island in the Gulf of Naples, Italy.

place_708.name: Ischia
place_708.description: An island in the Gulf of Naples, Italy.

place_710.name: Miseno
place_710.description: A port near Naples, Italy, to the north of the Gulf of Naples.

place_711.name: Salerno
place_711.description: City in south-western Italy, located on the Gulf of Salerno. Salerno is the capital city of the Italian province also named Salerno, in the Campania region of Italy.

place_714.name: Herculaneum
place_714.description: Herculaneum was an ancient Roman town, located in the modern-day comune of Ercolano, Campania, Italy.

place_1169.name: Mount Somma
place_1169.description: A mountain located in the Province of Naples, in the Campania region of southern Italy. It has a collapsed caldera of an older volcano, with Mount Vesuvius rising up from the center.

place_716.name: Theatre of Herculaneum
place_716.description: An archaeological site, buried by the eruption of Vesuvius in 79 CE and discovered by a farmer in 1709.

place_528.name: Solfatara Caldera
place_528.description: Solfatara di Pozzuoli is a volcanic crater near Naples. Though a dormant volcano, it emits jets of steam and sulphurous fumes.

place_717.name: Lake of Agnano
place_717.description: Lake Agnano, in southern Italy, was a lake in the crater of the extinct volcano (Agnano). It was drained in 1870.

place_718.name: Grotto del Cane
place_718.description: A cave by the Lake of Agnano, in southern Italy, that has a high concentration of carbon dioxide. Dogs were used to demonstrate this as a kind of tourist attraction, which the Shelleys refused to allow when they visited.

place_719.name: Astroni Crater
place_719.description: A nature reserve in an extinct volcanic crater near Naples, Italy.

place_720.name: Monte Nuovo
place_720.description: A cinder cone volcano near Naples, Italy, that first formed in the sixteenth century.

place_946.name: Cave Lazio
place_946.description: Subterranean chamber beneath the ancient city of Cumae, now Naples, Italy. Said to have been the dwelling place of Sibyl, ancient priestess and oracle.

place_721.name: Pozzuoli
place_721.description: A city within the city of Naples, Italy. It is the main city of the Phlegrean Peninsula.

place_827.name: Columns of Macellum
place_827.description: The columns contain borings made by the marine bivalve, Lithophaga. This indicated that the columns had been submerged beneath the sea and then uplifted. This observation was included in Charles Lyell's first volume of Principles of Geology, published shortly after Davy's death in 1830.

place_247.name: Alps
place_247.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

place_355.name: Rhone River
place_355.description: A major river in France and Switzerland.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_825.name: River Thames
place_825.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

place_950.name: Calpe
place_950.description: A municipality located on the Mediterranean coast of Spain.

place_951.name: Bosphorus
place_951.description: A passage of water in northwestern Turkey that connects the Black Sea to the Mediterranean. Forming part of the border between Asia and Europe, the strait bisects the city of Istanbul.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_954.name: Vale of Tempe
place_954.description: 10km long Greek gorge in northern Thessaly. Located between the mountains Ossa and Olympus, the Pineios River flows through the vale.

place_723.name: Lombardy
place_723.description: An administrative region of Italy in the north central part of the country.

place_724.name: Ligurian Hills
place_724.description: A region in north-western Italy located where the Alps and the Apennines meet.

place_763.name: Sandy Braes
place_763.description: Perhaps part of the Tardree Mountain complex, County Antrim, Northern Ireland, a volcanic vent complex with very rare rocks, which belong to the Tardree Rhyolite Complex, or Sallagh Braes, a mountain in County Antrim.

place_725.name: Monte Bolca
place_725.description: A locality near Verona, Italy, that is an important site for marine fossils, and has been known of since the 16th century.

place_622.name: Verona
place_622.description: Verona is a city located on the Adige River in the north of Italy.

place_726.name: Desenzano del Garda
place_726.description: A town in Lombardy located on the shore of Lake Garda.

place_727.name: Nîmes
place_727.description: A town in the region of Namur in Belgium, known for its limestone and caves.

place_728.name: Rimini
place_728.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_729.name: Adriatic Sea
place_729.description: The Adriatic Sea lies between the Italian Peninsula and the Balkan Peninsula. It is the northernmost section of the Mediterranean Sea.

place_730.name: Milan
place_730.description: A city in northern Italy, and the capital of Lombardy.

place_226.name: Geneva
place_226.description: Geneva is a city in Switzerland on the border with France.

place_731.name: Baths of Titus
place_731.description: Public baths built in Rome in 81 CE by the emperor Titus.

place_732.name: Porto fino
place_732.description: A coastal town in north-western Italy, within the city of Genoa.

place_1039.name: Genoa
place_1039.description: Italian port city in northwestern Italy. It is the capital of the Liguria region.

place_733.name: Baths of Nero
place_733.description: The Baths of Nero were a complex of Roman baths built in 64 CE.

place_179.name: Albulae Aquae
place_179.description: White Waters'; a group of springs to the west of Tivolo, Italy, and location of an ancient Roman settlement.

place_735.name: Moray Firth
place_735.description: A  large inlet on the north-east coast of Scotland.

place_736.name: Ticino River
place_736.description: The most important left-bank tributary of the Po River in Italy.

place_737.name: Adda River
place_737.description: The Adda is a river in northern Italy and is a tributary of the Po River.

place_1038.name: Iser
place_1038.description: The Isar River originates in the Karwendal mountains of the Alps, flowing through Bavaria in Germany, before reaching the Danube.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_1040.name: Paros
place_1040.description: A Greek island situated in the Mediterranean Sea, famous for its Parian marble: a fine-grained semi translucent pure-white and entirely flawless marble quarried during the classical era .

place_529.name: Tivoli, Lazio
place_529.description: Tivoli is a town north east of Rome and known for the waterfall on the Aniene River.

place_527.name: Aniene River
place_527.description: The Aniene is a river rising in the Apennines and flowing west to join the Tiber in northern Rome. It is famous for the Tivoli waterfall.

place_740.name: Nar
place_740.description: The Nera River. It runs through Romania and Serbia and is a tributary of the Danube.

place_848.name: Velino
place_848.description: A river in central Italy, a tributary of the Nera.

place_741.name: Siena
place_741.description: A city in Tuscany, and the capital of the Province of Siena.

place_782.name: Alexandrine Aqueduct
place_782.description: Also known as the Aquedutto Alexandrina or Aqua Alexandrina. Built in the 3rd century CE to carry water to Rome.

place_743.name: Radicofani
place_743.description: A town in the Province of Siena, Italy.

place_174.name: Pantano Borghese
place_174.description: On the outskirts of Rome south of Tivoli, an estate that since 1613 has belonged to the Borghese family.

place_170.name: Malagrotta
place_170.description: Malagrotta is a nature reserve in the region of Rome, Italy.

place_744.name: Marcellina
place_744.description: Marcellina is a district of Rome, Italy.

place_157.name: Malafede
place_157.description: Decima Malafede is a nature reserve within the district of Rome.

place_831.name: Marcigliana
place_831.description: A protected rural area to the north-east of Rome, now a nature reserve.

place_836.name: Pozzuoli
place_836.description: A city and region in the Italian region of Campania. The source for Pozzuoli Red, a natural earth pigment that was originally found in the volcanic areas of the region.

place_745.name: Languedoc
place_745.description: Languedoc is a historical province of France located on the south coast.

place_747.name: Sestri Levante
place_747.description: Sestri Levante is a town with the city of Genoa, Liguria, in Italy.

place_748.name: Pézenas
place_748.description: Pézenas is a commune in the Herault department of southern France, close to Saint-Thibéry.

place_806.name: St Thibery
place_806.description: Saint-Thibéry is a commune in the Hérault department in the Occitanie region of southern France. The village of Saint-Thibéry is built at the confluence of the Rivers Thongue and Hérault.

place_1087.name: Provence
place_1087.description: Provence is a region in southeastern France which borders the Mediterranean Sea and Italy.

place_538.name: Liguria
place_538.description: Liguria is a region of north west Italy. Its capital is Genoa.

place_1154.name: Chiavari
place_1154.description: Chiavari is a seaside municipality in the Ligurian region of Italy.

place_749.name: Mayenne
place_749.description: Mayenne is a department in north-west France.

place_750.name: Laval, Mayenne
place_750.description: Laval is the capital town of the Mayenne department in north-west France.

place_759.name: Ballachulish
place_759.description: Also known as Ballyhulish. A village in the Lochaber region of western Scotland.

place_758.name: Marseille
place_758.description: The second largest city in France and located on the Mediterranean coast.

place_757.name: Aix-en-Provence
place_757.description: Aix is a town in southern France, once the capital of the region of Provence.

place_287.name: Yorkshire
place_287.description: Yorkshire is a historic county in northern England and the largest by area size in the United Kingdom.

place_998.name: Pyrenees
place_998.description: The Pyrenees mountain range separates the Iberian Peninsula from the rest of Europe, stretching more than 430km between Spain and France and rising higher than 3,400m in elevation.

place_657.name: Canigou
place_657.description: A mountain peak located in the Pyrenees of southern France. Davy made sketches and wrote a poem about The Canigou in notebook 14I.

place_1156.name: Cour du commerce
place_1156.description: Cour du commerce is a Parisian passageway that dates back to 1776. It was a meeting place for intellectuals and revolutionaries. It now houses shops and one of Paris' oldest restaurants.

place_1157.name: Rue de Bourgogne No. 28
place_1157.description: The address of the apartment where Edme-François Jomard, French engineer and archaelogist, lived.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_1158.name: Lesketh How
place_1158.description: Built in 1844, and since redeveloped, Lesketh-How was the house near Ambleside, in the Lake District, where Davy's brother, the physician John Davy, lived. John Davy died there in January 1868.

otherwork_153.name: Memoirs of the Life of Sir Humphry Davy, Bart
otherwork_153.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_154.name: Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London
otherwork_154.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_259.name: Researches chemical and philosophical: chiefly concerning nitrous oxide or dephlogisticated nitrous air and its respiration
otherwork_259.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_278.name: Mémoires de Physique et de Chimie, de la Société d'Arcueil
otherwork_278.author: Gay Lussac
